skill.name: c4-modeling
skill.description: C4 architectural modeling for documenting software architecture. Use when creating architecture diagrams, planning new systems, communicating with stakeholders, or conducting architecture reviews.

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill that provides guidance for creating C4 architecture diagrams. It contains no executable code, network calls, file operations, or any potentially dangerous functionality. The skill only contains markdown files with instructions and examples for using Mermaid syntax.

content.value_statement: Software architecture is often poorly documented or outdated. This skill helps you create clear, hierarchical C4 diagrams that communicate effectively with both technical and non-technical stakeholders.
actual_capabilities: Generates C4 diagrams at all four abstraction levels
Provides Mermaid syntax examples and templates
Includes level-specific guidelines and best practices
Offers workflow checkpoints to prevent mixing abstraction levels
Contains detailed element descriptions and relationship labeling
limitations: Limited to C4 model structure - cannot create UML or other diagram types
No automatic code generation from diagrams
Does not validate diagram accuracy against actual code

use_cases.title: Document System Architecture
use_cases.description: Create comprehensive architecture documentation for new or existing systems using standardized C4 diagrams.

use_cases.title: Plan System Refactoring
use_cases.description: Visualize current architecture and plan refactoring efforts by mapping out container and component relationships.

use_cases.title: Communicate with Stakeholders
use_cases.description: Present technical architecture to business stakeholders using appropriate abstraction levels for each audience.

prompt_templates.title: Context Diagram
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Level 1 C4 context diagram for an e-commerce platform that shows customers, the main system, and external payment/shipping services. Include all relationships and use Mermaid syntax.

prompt_templates.title: Container Diagram
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a Level 2 C4 container diagram for the API server of a microservices platform. Show the web app, API gateway, services, and databases with their technologies.

prompt_templates.title: Component Diagram
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Level 3 C4 component diagram for a user authentication service. Include components for authentication, authorization, user management, and external integrations.

prompt_templates.title: Migration Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the current architecture of a monolithic Java application and propose a microservices migration strategy using C4 diagrams at appropriate levels.

output_examples.input: Create a C4 context diagram for a banking mobile app
output: ‚Ä¢ System: Banking Mobile App (allows account management)

best_practices: Always start with Level 1 context diagrams before diving deeper
Include technology choices for containers and components
Label all relationships with meaningful descriptions
Use boundaries to group related elements logically
anti_patterns: Mixing abstraction levels in the same diagram
Creating code-level diagrams for simple CRUD operations
Skipping context diagrams and jumping to container level
Forgetting to include external systems and dependencies

faq.question: What is the C4 model?
faq.answer: C4 is a hierarchical approach to software architecture documentation with four levels: Context, Container, Component, and Code.

faq.question: Which tools support C4 diagrams?
faq.answer: Mermaid, Structurizr, PlantUML, and various diagramming tools support C4 syntax for creating architecture diagrams.

faq.question: When should I use Level 4 (Code) diagrams?
faq.answer: Only for complex or critical code sections that require detailed documentation, such as intricate algorithms or key design patterns.

faq.question: Can I mix different diagram levels?
faq.answer: No, each diagram should focus on a single abstraction level to maintain clarity and avoid confusion.

faq.question: How do I choose the right diagram level?
faq.answer: Consider your audience: Context for everyone, Container for technical stakeholders, Component for developers, Code for implementers.

faq.question: What makes a good C4 diagram?
faq.answer: Clear element descriptions, labeled relationships, appropriate technology choices, and boundaries that group related components.
